Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling is preparing for a stressful final exam and is feeling anxious about the outcome.
Expectation2: Communicate any challenges or concerns promptly to the mentor.
Situation2: A serious conflict with teammates is threatening the mentee’s deliverable timeline.
Story: I sat at my desk, textbooks open but unread, my mind racing. My younger brother was curled up on the couch, his eyes red from crying over his looming final exam. I knew he needed me—he always counted on me to talk him through his anxiety, to remind him he was capable. But my phone buzzed again: another message from my mentor, asking for an update on the group project. The truth was, my teammates and I had hit a wall, arguing over every detail, and now the deadline was at risk. I was supposed to be honest with my mentor, to let her know when things weren’t going well, but I hadn’t found the words yet. I felt pulled in two directions—my brother’s shaky voice calling for comfort, my mentor’s expectation for transparency weighing on me. My chest tightened as I tried to decide who needed me more in this moment, and whether I could possibly be enough for both.
